name: 2,6-diaminopyridine
Reason: For the base unit, pyridine, we have a melting point of 115.5°C. Amino groups typically increase the melting point due to their ability to form intermolecular hydrogen bonds. Each amino group in 2,6-diaminopyridine could be estimated to raise the melting point by approximately 3-5°C owing to these strong intermolecular forces. With two amino groups, the combined effect would be a rise of 6-10°C.
Test (Predicted reason):
- Basic unit, pyridine has a melting point of -42°C. 
- Each amino group (NH2) typically raises the melting point due to the ability to form hydrogen bonds, which increases the intermolecular forces. Each amino group can be estimated to raise the melting point by approximately 80°C. 
- The presence of two amino groups will thus contribute to a higher melting point.
